Ratgrub Hero Review - Empires and Puzzles

Ratgrub has scurried into the Goblin family with a cheese-loving friend in tow. Initially dismissed as a weak imitation of Guardian Hippo, a crucial balance update has turned this rodent courtier into a PvE and Raid powerhouse. Learn how to unleash the Princess.
Ratgrub: The Rodent King of Chain Reactions
Ratgrub, The Rodent Royal: Unleashing the Princess of Pain

Ratgrub is a Legendary Holy hero from the notorious Goblin family, released in September 2025. When he first scurried onto the scene, the community reaction was colder than a dead rat, with many dismissing him as a slower, weaker version of Guardian Hippo. However, following a much-needed balance update that bulked up his furry companion, Ratgrub has found his niche. He operates as a unique hybrid of support and damage dealer, relying on his "Rat Princess" Mega Minion to unleash devastating chain attacks. He is currently a top-tier choice for players who love synergy-heavy teams and seeing enemy health bars melt away in a cascade of special skills.

Ratgrub’s design is quintessentially Goblin: a mix of the grotesque and the oddly charming. He stands there with a mischievous, toothy grin, affectionately feeding a piece of cheese to a massive white rat perched on his shoulder—the "Rat Princess" herself. The color palette is dominated by the sickly greens of the goblin skin and the rich purples of his courtier attire, contrasting with the bright yellow Holy element icon. It’s a fun departure from the serious, armored warriors we usually see; this is a guy who brings his pet to the battlefield and expects you to deal with it.
Ratgrub boasts a modern stat line that keeps him competitive in the current meta.

With a base power of 1237 (rising significantly with Limit Breaks), Ratgrub is well-positioned among late-2025 heroes. His stat distribution is fairly balanced, with a slight lean towards survivability (Defense and Health), which is ideal for a Cleric whose main job is to keep his Mega Minion alive. Compared to the absolute latest heroes like the Titan Hunters or Astral Demons, his attack stat isn't the highest, but his massive health pool allows his Mega Minion to inherit a substantial amount of HP, which is the key to his effectiveness.

This skill is the centerpiece of Ratgrub's kit. It summons a "Rat Princess" Mega Minion for himself. While the minion provides a meat shield, its real purpose is offensive. As long as the Rat Princess is alive,
another ally casts a special skill, Ratgrub (via the minion) deals massive damage to

This mechanic is very similar to Guardian Hippo, but with a key difference: the effect is tied to the physical presence of the Mega Minion rather than a buff. This makes it "undispellable" in the traditional sense—you can't just use a dispeller to stop the damage; you have to kill the minion. The balance update improved the Mega Minion's survivability (up to 40% HP in live versions compared to early beta), making it much harder to remove casually. The damage output is capped at once per ally per turn, preventing infinite loops, but in a standard turn where you fire 3 or 4 heroes, the cumulative damage is catastrophic.
Let’s break down the damage potential, assuming a Limit Broken Ratgrub with roughly 1600 Attack:
Average (10 tiles). With a Level 29 Magic/Styx troop or a Level 23+ Mana troop and the Cleric mana node, he can shave this down, though hitting the 9-tile breakpoint requires significant investment.
~35-40% of caster's max HP. If Ratgrub has 3000 HP, the minion has ~1050-1200 HP. That is a substantial shield.
If you have 4 other allies charged and fire them after Ratgrub:
This is roughly equivalent to firing a dedicated AOE nuker almost three times over.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
The Goblin family brings a distinct flavor of chaos to the board, primarily focused on messing with the enemy's accuracy and health.

This passive is what makes Goblins so annoying to fight. If Ratgrub gets hit by a special skill, there is a chance he just casually strips away the enemy's boosted health. In the current meta where Boosted Health is prevalent (thanks to heroes like Hathor, Cleopatra, and the toon healers), this is a potent, albeit reactive, counter.

When Ratgrub fires, he has a coin-flip chance (50%) to either deal extra damage or blind the entire enemy team (-25% accuracy). While the damage is nice chip damage, the accuracy debuff is the real prize here. A global blind can cause key enemy dispellers or snipers to miss, protecting your Mega Minion for another turn.

is fantastic for Ratgrub. Since his entire value proposition rests on keeping his Mega Minion alive, taking significantly less damage from special skills ensures he stays healthy enough to keep the minion protected. It forces enemies to rely on tile damage or specific minion-removal heroes to deal with him.
Upon release, Ratgrub was overshadowed by the memory of Guardian Hippo and the perception that 35% HP for a Mega Minion was too fragile. The initial community verdict was "pass."

With the adjustments to his Minion's durability and the damage multiplier, Ratgrub has vaulted into relevance. While he lacks the Fast speed of Hippo, the sheer durability of the Mega Minion in the era of 3000+ HP heroes means the "Rat Princess" sticks around much longer than a 3-turn buff.

He is a top-tier threat in Rush Wars and a devastating offensive tool in raids. In PvE events (like Challenge Events or Towers), he is arguably S-tier, as you can use mana potions on your other heroes to trigger his AOE repeatedly, clearing waves in seconds.
, which gives him a chance to resist mana-stopping ailments. This is excellent for ensuring he fires his skill.

. By maximizing his health, you maximize the minion's health, making it harder to destroy and keeping the passive damage effect active longer.

Absolutely trivializes map stages and event waves when combined with mana potions.
High base health creates a very beefy Mega Minion.
Heroes who destroy minions (e.g., Grimsteel, Ogima, Lunar) or specifically counter Mega Minions shut him down completely.
He does very little on his own. If he is the last hero alive, he is effectively useless.

Heroes like Madhammer or the new Mimics who might steal or manipulate minions can turn the Princess against you.

If you pull Ratgrub early, focus on keeping him alive. He pairs well even with 3-star and 4-star heroes who have fast mana (like Bane or Poppy). Fire him first, then everyone else. He will carry you through the map stages easily.

Ratgrub is a luxury toy that hits like a truck. He is worth the darts if you lack a Guardian Hippo or want a second option for War teams. In the current "Big Minion" meta, he fits right in. Don't sleep on his defense team potential in the corner—if he fires late when the attacker is out of specials, he can punish them severely.
The initial reception to Ratgrub was skeptical. Beta testers remarked,
"The Mega Minion’s HP is lower than W3K minion’s HP. It doesn’t look very logical."
"People are worried about the MM health? This guy gets G.Hippo as their MM... Id like to know if it would also stack."
However, post-buff, the sentiment shifted. As YouTuber
"He is a lot of fun to use. honestly might be my new favorite hero... the damage from the mega minion... hits all of them."
The community went from calling him "Ratatouille's reject" to a respected damage dealer, proving that a little health buff goes a long way.

Ratgrub is a classic "Zero to Hero" story. Initially dismissed for his fragility, he has chewed his way through the meta to become a formidable force. While he requires a specific team setup to shine, when the stars align and the specials fly, there is nothing quite as satisfying as watching a rodent orchestrate the complete destruction of the enemy team. He is a must-have for players who enjoy big numbers and flashy combos.
A cheese-loving champion who is definitely worth the trap.
